title: I voluntarily surrendered my rv to the bank 6-7 years ago and I still have it. Now what?
question: They sent someone to pick it up, they had the wrong towing capabilities, so they weren't able to take the rv. That was 6-7 years ago and I haven't heard from anyone. What can I do with the rv now?
answers:
This is a very good question. You still have title to the vehicle.

If the vehicle has any value and runs, then after this amount of time, with a default, if the lender doesn't want it back, then you can either begin charging them storage fees, or alternatively request that they release the title to you.

If you filed for bankruptcy 6 or 7 years ago, and were discharged 6 or 7 years ago, the lender owes you sufficient storage fees that you can treat it as abandoned property. You can place a lien on it for the storage fees provided you gave the lender notice of the lien.

Alternatively, you can turn the vehicle into the police and they will advertise it for 90 days. After that you pay the storage fees to get it back with title or they sell it and pay your storage fees.

There are a number of routes to take. It all depends if you want it or not.

This often happens. Contact the creditor. Request that they come and get the vehicle or surrender title to you. If you surrendered the vehicle in a BK, you have no personal liability to creditor. However, creditor retains security interest in vehicle. You will not be able to sell the vehicle until the underlying security interest is released.

I concur with the advice given by my colleagues, however more information is needed to give you the best advice. Under the doctrine of laches, you may be able to retain the vehicle because they have not taken action to recover it and probably have forgotten about it. If it has any value to you, I would not recommend doing anything to wake up the lender. Are you using it? Is it insured? Have you been paying the annual registration? If it has no value, THEN you can contact the lender and remind them about it. If they still won't do anything, park it where it can be towed/impounded and let the lender worry about what to do next.

You should contact a competent Bankruptcy or debt collection attorney in California before you act. However, you can try and have the creditor collect the collateral again but ensure that you obtain in writing that you have voluntarily relinquished it.
You can write to the lender and request that they either come and get the vehicle, or give you the title so you can dispose of it.

If you are filing for bankruptcy protection from the deficiency, you can have your attorney file a motion to redeem the property for a nominal amount ($1). If they don't respond, then you get the clean title to keep and use, sell, donate, whatever you want. Consult a bankruptcy attorney for details.
